↳ In-reply-to ¬ª Just looked at how twtxt.net and yarn.social is coming along. It's definitely something for the community to be proud of, IMO.

@codebalion@twtxt.prismdragon.net You are right (in general) ‚Äì But in this particular case (which I won‚Äôt disclose for privacy reasons) there is more to this, but I‚Äôm glad the conversation/discussions happened anyway. üëå Basically there is a lot of ‚Äúmisunderstanding‚Äù in this case, which I‚Äôm hoping to try to help clear up by writing an FAQ on the Landing page at some point when my neck/back has healed up (injured myself recently and am in quite a bit of pain) ü§û

↳ In-reply-to ¬ª Long time no post.

@codebalion@twtxt.prismdragon.net Well I‚Äôm glad to see you back ü§ó The nice thing about using Twtxt as your ‚Äúsocial media‚Äù is its ‚Äúslow‚Äù ‚Äì And as some have called it, Yarn.social / Twtxt is the non-social ‚Äúsocial media‚Äù üòÖ

↳ In-reply-to ¬ª Just looked at how twtxt.net and yarn.social is coming along. It's definitely something for the community to be proud of, IMO.

@codebalion@twtxt.prismdragon.net Thank you so much! üôè That means an awful lot to me and everyone that‚Äôs contributed over the years to making Yarn.social / Twtxt ‚Äôs ecosystem possible üëå

↳ In-reply-to ¬ª Long time no post.

@codebalion@twtxt.prismdragon.net Why hello there! üëã Welcome (or welcome back?) ü§ó
I think at this point, I should write an FAQ section on the landing page ü§î
content.value: I think at this point, I should write an FAQ section on the landing page ü§î

content.html:
↳ In-reply-to ¬ª @prologic (re: Just discovered ...) On the one hand, twtxt has become more popular thanks to Yarn.social. On the other hand, subject and hashtag extensions took away the simplicity of the protocol. For example, it is impossible to understand which conversation (#base32hash) a tweet refers to or to reply to a tweet without going to a yarn.social pod. Compare with re: in this tweet which can be written without using any client at all

For example jenny creates Maildir email threads out of them I believe and then you can use mutt to interact with your Twtxt feeds which then fully supports the Twt Hash and Twt Subject exts very nicely (and many Jenny uses do use Mutt).

↳ In-reply-to ¬ª @prologic (re: Just discovered ...) On the one hand, twtxt has become more popular thanks to Yarn.social. On the other hand, subject and hashtag extensions took away the simplicity of the protocol. For example, it is impossible to understand which conversation (#base32hash) a tweet refers to or to reply to a tweet without going to a yarn.social pod. Compare with re: in this tweet which can be written without using any client at all

@win0err@kolesnikov.se So as long as you have a ‚Äúdecent client‚Äù (for various definition of) that has some kind of cache and/or long-term storage, you can easily use the same calculations and hash and form your own display of the same ‚Äúthreads‚Äù that can span many feeds.

↳ In-reply-to ¬ª @prologic (re: Just discovered ...) On the one hand, twtxt has become more popular thanks to Yarn.social. On the other hand, subject and hashtag extensions took away the simplicity of the protocol. For example, it is impossible to understand which conversation (#base32hash) a tweet refers to or to reply to a tweet without going to a yarn.social pod. Compare with re: in this tweet which can be written without using any client at all

@win0err@kolesnikov.se Sorry I didn‚Äôt see your @-mention until now. So sorry for the late reply. The thing is pretty much every single extension was the formalisation of what was already happening in the ecosystem and community (which at the time was largely dead). ‚Äì The only exception is the Twt Hash Extension (which was also created by e member of the cummunity and the community agreed and we formalised that too) in order to support ‚Äúproper threading‚Äù.

We generally have discussed as a community ideas of changing how this works, but we can never agree on why we should change it or how it would be better designed. I actually didn‚Äôt come up with the design, some other very clever person did, and the thing is it gives us unique and interesting properties that clients can use for various display purposes that you cannot get any other way. Namely that each Twt and the calculated Hash are ‚Äúcontent addressable‚Äù.

↳ In-reply-to ¬ª @prologic @eaplmx To be fair, the only thing I can think of that makes Yarn feeds not be "standard twtxt" is the disregard for twt size (which many others also do with their non-yarn clients). But sure, I can see how reading these feeds might be frustrating: too big posts, markdown everywhere, linebreak characters, emojis... But I'll consider it the "freedom of the user" to decide whether or not to follow a feed written in a certain style. The provocative metadata comment? Easy (and better) to just ignore.

yep, you are right! Sorry, I didn‚Äôt see your reply initially ü§ó

↳ In-reply-to ¬ª @prologic Don't ask me, I just translated what he said, and what was his thinking, because you wanted to know.

thanks I really appreciate that! üôè

I‚Äôm going to be so bold as to claim:

You cannot turn an existing decentralised open source ecosystem into a proprietary one.

Not possible.
content.value:
I‚Äôm going to be so bold as to claim:

You cannot turn an existing decentralised open source ecosystem into a proprietary one.

Not possible.

content.html:
↳ In-reply-to ¬ª Hi @prologic I tried to understand the point of @lucidiot, and what he actually doesn't like is not the extensions on itself (even if he prefers #hashtag instead of # < hashtag url> (that I understand)), because he also uses some extension.

Or rather that is to say‚Ä¶ How the hell do you make a truely decentralised ecosystem ‚Äúproprietary‚Äù in the first place?! ü§¶‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è I cannot think of any example of this ‚Äì This is why most (if not all?) profitable ‚Äúsocial media‚Äù(s) are all ‚Äúcentralised‚Äù systems or ‚Äúdistributed networks‚Äù, so they retain control.

Yarn.social / Twtxt (the ecosystem) has very little to no control over anything. In fact the extensions themselves were a formalisation of what the community was (as you clearly point out) doing and still is doing.

Or rather that is to say‚Ä¶ How the hell do you make a truely decentralised ecosystem ‚Äúproprietary‚Äù in the first place?! ü§¶‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è I cannot think of any example of this ‚Äì This is why most (if not all?) profitable ‚Äúsocial media‚Äù(s) are all ‚Äúcentralised‚Äù systems or ‚Äúdistributed networks‚Äù, so they retain control.

content.html:
↳ In-reply-to ¬ª Hi @prologic I tried to understand the point of @lucidiot, and what he actually doesn't like is not the extensions on itself (even if he prefers #hashtag instead of # < hashtag url> (that I understand)), because he also uses some extension.

@tkanos I have to ask‚Ä¶

Actually what he doesn‚Äôt like, is the fear that you may extend the protocol and once it‚Äôs adopted by everybody, make it proprietary and oblige everybody to only uses your platform. (here https://brainshit.fr/read/242)

How?! ü§¶‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è How in the hell do you turn an open spec (Twtxt and Extensions) into something ‚Äúproprietary‚Äù. They are already open sourced and licensed under the terms of the MIT License. They ar archived by the Internet Archive. There is no way to go back on this.

Many clients are also MIT licensed or similar as well (yarnd specifically is AGPLv3 but for a reason).

The simple fact is this‚Ä¶ (And the nice thing), Twtxt clients of any kind are really just that, a client. There is no protocol (never has been), only a specification and extensions. You just host a feed using any HTTP, Gopher or Gemini server.

So therefore Twtxt / Yarn is 100% decentralised ‚Äì in the truest sense.

It is not possible to do what @lucidiot@tilde.town fears (worries) about in the first place.

How?! ü§¶‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è How in the hell do you turn an open spec (Twtxt and Extensions) into something ‚Äúproprietary‚Äù. They are already open sourced and licensed under the terms of the MIT License. They ar archived by the Internet Archive. There is no way to go back on this.
Many clients are also MIT licensed or similar as well (yarnd specifically is AGPLv3 but for a reason).
The simple fact is this‚Ä¶ (And the nice thing), Twtxt clients of any kind are really just that, a client. There is no protocol (never has been), only a specification and extensions. You just host a feed using any HTTP, Gopher or Gemini server.
So therefore Twtxt / Yarn is 100% decentralised ‚Äì in the truest sense.
It is not possible to do what @lucidiot@tilde.town fears (worries) about in the first place.

content.html:
↳ In-reply-to ¬ª I hate to be the one that instigates and continues to make true the saying "the few spoil it for the many", but off the back of this thread; I have to ask...

@tkanos You raise very good points üëå And thank you for the support üôè Could not agree more! üíØ

↳ In-reply-to ¬ª I hate to be the one that instigates and continues to make true the saying "the few spoil it for the many", but off the back of this thread; I have to ask...

@tkanos That‚Äôs a really good question. We probably need to evaluate the reasons why we would‚Ä¶ Currently Yarn.social is really a landing page for a community of Twtxt clients, Specifications and Extensions that all work together nicely. There are numerous implementations and more being discovered all the time. ‚Äì However if the hostility from (shall we call) ‚ÄúTwtxt‚Äù purists continues, I see no other choice but to pack up everything we‚Äôve done and hard fork and break away.

Or is there a 3rd option I don‚Äôt see? ü§î ‚Äì I think the hardest part of all this is the amount of work, energy and effort we have all poured into this project and community only to have it thrown back in our face üò¢ ‚Äì Work/Energy/Effort (btw) that is completely FREE (as in freedom of choice) and free as in voluntarily created, maintained and costs $0.00 to anyone.

I hate to be the one that instigates and continues to make true the saying ‚Äúthe few spoil it for the many‚Äù, but off the back of this thread; I have to ask‚Ä¶

Should we as a community make a decision here and hard fork Twtxt and no longer actively use it? In other words, break compatibility in such a way that Yarn.social no longer uses or is compatible with Twtxt.

As much as I really don‚Äôt want to do this, and never intended for this to happens, the question has to be asked. This isn‚Äôt the first time the ‚Äúfew‚Äù that exist in the Twtxt community have been hostile, and this likely won‚Äôt be the last either üò¢

What say y‚Äôall? ü§ó
content.value:

As much as I really don‚Äôt want to do this, and never intended for this to happens, the question has to be asked. This isn‚Äôt the first time the ‚Äúfew‚Äù that exist in the Twtxt community have been hostile, and this likely won‚Äôt be the last either üò¢
What say y‚Äôall? ü§ó

↳ In-reply-to ¬ª I switched from twtxt client to twtwt (https://github.com/win0err/twtwt). It's a pre-alpha version now, but it works pretty well and so much faster than the official twtxt client by @buckket. Feel free to check it out :-)

↳ In-reply-to ¬ª Just discovered @lucidiot's feed and am very saddened to see anyone take this position Media #Yarn.social is NOT trying to take anything over or become a "monopoly" ü§¶‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è

@eaplmx The issue is not @lucidiot@tilde.town desire to remain with the simpler (unextended) Twtxt spec. That‚Äôs totally fine. It is this ‚Äúlash out‚Äù and calling out Yarn.social in his feed, as if it were a bad thing that is truly deeply offensive to the work countless folks have done over two and a bit years now and the growing community that continues to build clients, spawn pods, and so on. It‚Äôs like a ‚Äúshove it in your face‚Äù kind of moment to see something like this, even borderline ‚Äúprejudice‚Äù really.

People are free to use Twtxt however they wish, and they are even free to use the Extensions we built, or not. So you are 100% right there.

@abucci@anthony.buc.ci I really don‚Äôt know mate, I really don‚Äôt know. Its really disappointing to see to be honest and I‚Äôm really quite upset by this.

That is to say; we just formalized what was already commonly being done.
